posts.name: Finusk
posts.com:
LAST TIME:
>We exit Miam Cavern and enter Seaside Village, where we pick up a replacement Stando and take a detour to Alola to pick up my favorite pokemon, Sandshrew
>We wait another obscene amount of time for a new team, catch a Turtonator which takes forever to name, grind a bit, then enter the Misty Cavern to rescue a baby Lapras
>After defeating the thugs' leader, Zyklon, I get an egg
>After evolving Fletchling and Woot, I make a wrong turn when going back to the Pokemon Center and meet Zaydolf again, who tells me his plans on starting a painting business, and get into a battle I'm unprepared for, but my recently caught turtle saves me
>I buy some stuff from the town's various shops, including some brittle bones to boost my Fletchinder's speed, and two power items for EV training. They're broken, because they give 4 EVs in every stat per defeated foe, instead of 8 in a specific stat.
>On the bright side, we discover an infinite source of sharp beaks which can't be sold
>I then challenge the city's gym, and fight Lomar, the food-type specialist, and sweep his team with birds, earning the Pizza Badge. We also catch a Tortaco.
>Meanwhile, Zaydolf gets rejected by the Juvites and he learns about their conspiracy to take over the world

Whiteout counter: 0
Badges: 2
Natural shinies: 0

TALLY OF ATROCITY:
Confirmed deaths: 1

TALLY OF FAIL:

not gonna continue immediately tonight so I'll just build a new team instead.
Who's coming for tomorrow? Evens
fakemon in order:
>Slimee: normal type generic RPG enemy
>Maverock: tech type special attacker
>Lusfairy: heart/fairy special attacker with plenty of split evolutions
>Wolfman: ice type physical wall
>Bashkull: rock type knockoff cranidos
>Stingscorp: bug/poizon crazy mutha fucka with merciless ability and 120 base attack
>Smoball: obligatory earlygame ice type
>Foggeam: poison/steam physical attacker with a status-cluttered level up movepool
>Humanoid Rhyhorn: bone/rock physical attacker
>Brynhildcer: heart/fire mixed attacker
>Starvipup: dark type lillipup variant
>Miaby: fire/zombie magby variant
>Cosmock: rock/cosmic pre-evo for both Solrock and Lunatone. it's adamant so I'll evolve it into Solrock
>Stando: steel/fighting jojo reference with lots of different forms (see https://pokemonwack.fandom.com/wiki/Stando for full list, just pick one)
>Monkid: filler normal type giftmon
>Tortaco: extremely bulky food/normal physical attacker with weak armor it can't exploit due to 20 base speed and relaxed nature. essentially shuckle if it wasn't extremely passive

This one worked, here's some AI art

Picrel is the long overdue Aelita and Amber art that the AI seemed to generate pretty well considering there were 2 characters. Reference art works well.
First off, remember this image? https://files.catbox.moe/ll8ui0.png
An original drawfag classic and unfortunately the only hand drawn Aelita lewd out there (for now). Musk dug it out of the Reborn archives and sent it to me, I ran it through the AI as a reference and got these
https://files.catbox.moe/vyj6xi.png
https://files.catbox.moe/pairvw.png
all things considered I don't think the AI knew what the fuck it was looking at but after a few generations it made some passable art. I dropped the reference and then generated some normal art with tags
https://files.catbox.moe/txkmw4.png
The AI doesn't do very well with generating faceless males but when it does the art is generally good
https://files.catbox.moe/0kmfso.png
The AI does do pretty well with POV art, though
https://files.catbox.moe/i1cgvi.png
Personally, I prefer when the generations look more like the character I'm trying to make images of
https://files.catbox.moe/mlspy7.png
I know someone requested paizuri so here we are, the nipples visible through the shirt is just an extra surprise the AI decided to throw in
https://files.catbox.moe/8okqah.png
for those who REALLY like muscles
https://files.catbox.moe/11mx6f.png
this one's pretty similar to a previous image but I decided to post it anyway

Also be sure to read the (mostly) AI generated writefagging that I made
https://mega.nz/file/XqAghQqY#vXi4aPdlNoO0cZrRMlsGy8wh9jt-Tx_BT-rq_d57ABE

>>53054559
I prefer the dynamic that Grusha hates Larry because of his "normal" act, willingly disregarding all his talent and potential his whole life when some of us had ambitions we had to give up unwillingly. It adds some spice and an excuse to explore what drove them into their niches. What makes Larry feel that being a corporate drone is his only option? Does Grusha fear being chained down to the one career? I feel like they'd be terrible communicating in words, so it'd be things like sharing a love of soba or a refreshingly fast bird flight that appeals to them thinking "he's not that polar opposite from me after all". They sit silently side by side, begrudgingly at first, but neither can stay mad over a warming broth. By the time they aren't grumbling about one another everyone is confused about what happened while they weren't looking, how come those two seem almost friendly now? And then a small spat occurs and their hopes drop.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I'm excited and nervous about starting Emerald after finishing Crystal. Do you guys particularly concerned with Natures/Abilities/EVs or do you just roll with the punches?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53027277
Depends on the encounter and game state, some pokemon become liabilities with a bad nature, IVs, and movepool; like -SpA Ralts with poor SpA IVs. While fine as a Gardevoir later on due to the huge Base Stat it won't be strong enough to get there as a normal party member considering it's after the fourth badge. Then at the point where you could level it up to use it, you'll have access to other pokemon, hopefully ones with better stat distributions.

Some notable ones with the issue are
>Treecko
The worst starter in terms of early-mid game
>Poochyena
Without a decent Atk/SpA, won't do enough damage until you it before Wattson. Has Howl but is way too frail to use it. Mightyena has some utility however.
>Beautifly
Too weak and limited in moves to handle poor offensive stats
>Lombre and Nuzleaf
They need stats to balance out their awful movepools
>Ralts
As stated above

Then there's the inverse
>Mudkip and Torchic
Decent moves, coverage, and resistances balance out poor stats
>Zigzagoon
Has pick Up and gets early Headbutt which is a STAB 70 power move with a flinch chance, that with Sand-Attack, Tail Whip and Growl gives a way to set up for other pokemon
>Taillow and Wingull
Access to early Wing Attack and Water gun, respectively, are extremely useful and strong.
>Dustox
It doesn't rely on its stats as it's focused on status and support

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This one cut a little closer than it should have, but 10th game in the challenge is done

Lorelei and Bruno were dealt with Calm Mind sweeps from Slowbro, then instead of risking it through the status effects that Agatha tried to put me through, I pulled out Substitute Raticate. Deny status effects then sweep with Shadow Ball

Things didn't go as planned vs Lance, though. Blogpost incoming
>lead Butterfree to sleep Gyarados so Slowbro can setup
>Gyarados immediately wakes up
>to kill Gyarados and the incoming Dragonair but now Slowbro is at 1/3
>swap to Nidoking
>ice beam city
>freezes Dragonite
>promptly thaws and kills Nidoking with a crit Outrage
Ninetales dealt the final blow but that sucked, now I'm missing a lot of coverage and bulk vs Rival

>lead Raticate vs Pidgeot
>TWave then set up sub on Sand Attack
>kill with Return
>kill Alakazam with Shadow Ball
>Exeggutor comes in and TWave'd
>switch Slowbro and Calm Mind twice
>Ice Beam the eggs
>Gyarados comes in
>crits Bite twice
>leaves me at 20 HP
>in a panic, misplay and switch out, should have just sacrificed him for a free switch
>send out Butterfree
>Toxic then Protect/Psychic until we're both in the red
>predict his Full Restore and put him to sleep in the same turn (felt really good about this one)
>swap into Raticate and set up another sub, then kill with Return
>Charizard comes out and Fire Blasts the sub away
>swap into Ninetales and absorb his next Fire Blast with Flash Fire
>for some reason it Fire Blasts again while I confuse and slowly chip it with HP Electric
>Rhydon comes in
>can't safely switch into anything since Rock Tomb or EQ will kill
>confuse and burn before going down
>send out Raticate
>sub for safety and kill with Return

I had plenty of misplays (including not bringing a 6th to E4) but some of my predictions left me feeling really good, and I can't feel too bad by going all the way with Raticate and Butterfree lol. Rest easy, Mr. Nido and Azsakano.

Clair time, after an excessively long and pointless Rocket and grinding session.
Plan? Lead Parasect, Spore Gyarados and sucks him dry I guess.

Kingdra next, I try to switch back to Parasect in hopes of more Sleep spreading, but take too much damage from Not Hydro Pump.
No problem, Miltank can stall as long as is needed and eventually win.
Gyarados comes back in, I switch to Sudowoodo, get a Rock Slide miss after which Gyarados waves up and deals notable damage before falling to a more successful Rock Slide.
Second Dragonair comes out, at which point I go to Girafarig, failing to get the kill due to Paralysis before going back to Mommy Milkers for a lossless win.

Did not go ideally, but good enough.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53054201
It was topped by:
>Crystal
>Emerald
>Platinum
>HGSS
>B2W2
>USUM
>SwSh
>SV
So yes it has been topped and will probably be topped again. A fantastic and highly refreshing entry in the series, but ultimately not a highlight, it is to me perfect proof that diverting from the core Pokemon formula can produce a beautiful game, but most likely cannot surpass any definitive generation titles. Arceus feels as if it’s the lesser two games of a generation, like a Diamond and Pearl that will never receive a Platinum; for all the mature and fascinating new turns that the game takes, there are some glaring flaws that prevent it from reasonably being listed among the definitive generation titles. It sounds so consoomer, but that game could really benefit from a third version/paid DLC more than the average set of games. I think Arceus will age to have a reputation like X and Y, a fun and memorable but relatively empty tale of what could’ve been, with achievements that feel diminished by their better implementation in subsequent titles. If this game is the start of a new side series, I think some amazing things will follow, I hope that future entries feel more definitive. As it stands, Legends is a solid 7/10; great for the Pokemon series at large, but shy of being a valid contender for the God tier sliver of games. As much as it may make people seethe, I’d say it shares a tier with SwSh and SV just below the tier of the other games greentexted above.

I /am/ him, I was responding to myself to correct my mistake. My sole point was to give my thoughts on PLA in regards to the series at large. Anyone who buys into the “war” between PLA and SV is brain damaged and not worth factoring into the discussion.

>>53056016
It really is the DLC for me; I definitely could be biased from the fact that I only experienced the definitive edition, but the legendary quests and DLC wild areas felt really nice and like the first glimmer of what I always imagined Pokemon could be. Granted PLA and SV both blew it out of the water in that regard, but it doesn’t change the fact that it was a fun experience. I was getting really tired in the stretch between XY and LGPE, SwSh restored my ability to have fun with the games, I thought there were some fun characters in there, a solid dex, and a fun enough campaign with some great DLC inclusion that made it really feel like exploration for the first time since Unova. I admittedly don’t go looking for nor do I factor in fan discourse to my own experiences, so I was a little shocked to see how brutally people tore the games apart. Aside from cutting the dex (which was always inevitable in my eyes, especially approaching 1000), I struggle to see how the common complaints of that game are exclusive to that game. Like if you think SwSh has bad graphics I’m struggling to believe that you can sincerely think PLA has good graphics, you get what I mean? Pokemon is a series that’s always plagued by the same issues and held back by the same arbitrary limitations, and within that frame I found SwSh to be the first game I wanted to consistently keep playing after I started since B2W2, and that feeling of fresh fun has oozed into both PLA and SV.

>>53056063
They are close to each other, history will remember them so, and so will you once you’re less immediately passionate and more objectively critical.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53056102
>What level of cuck consumer puts these pieces of shit even near the same level as Emerald, FRLG or PLA?
Evidently I do, and while I’ll explain myself I doubt you’re interested in hearing me out. I already gave my lengthy SwSh take, but I might as well back up the other two. The 3DS was a horrible era for Pokemon, and USUM was the light at the end of the tunnel. I know there’s a lot of animosity towards genwunners, but I grew up in Pokemania, so call me a cringe consoomer all you want, I enjoyed the massive crossover of the Ultra games, it felt like the right mixture of fan service and original region; a vacation stroll through series history with a notable highlight in Kanto, for an original player it was the perfect end end of the series’ worst era. Traveling through space to battle aliens while Multiverse Giovanni unites all the villains kicks ass, and if you need me to justify that assessment then you have no joy in your life. The PLA vs. SV forced narrative really confuses me when they’re such similar games, I’ve been loving SV for the same reasons I love PLA. The overworld Pokemon interactions, the open environment navigation, the more interesting and personal storylines and character relationships. It’s saying water’s wet to say that the games have their bugs and flaws, but I seem to remember the trainer who can clip through ledges in Emerald or being able to corrupt Yellow into catching Mew, or DP into finding shinies; every game is massively fucked, GF are shit developers through every release, it’s as consistent as their good music. The sheer exploration and freedom of SV makes it a standout entry in the series and, again, you have to have no joy in your life to it concede that point. I’m not a blind consumer who praises GF’s every move, the entire 3DS era and both switch remakes have been garbage, I’m just unafraid to admit that I think they’ve been killing it in their major outings - SwSh, PLA, *and* SV all included.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53043105
the basic idea is
>kill all surrounding spawns without spawning target pokemon
>go stand right next to where an overworld mon will spawn, but doesnt actually spawn
>save and edge closer, restart game if you accidentally spawn it
>date skip to a clear day
>go to check summary screen of one of your pokemon and click the right thumb stick
>track the attacks
>0 = physical, 1 = special
>do this 128 times
>put this number into the program
>it will tell you how many more stick clicks you need to do in order to get to a shiny
>you need to exit the menu about 4-6 clicks early and walk forward
>once it has spawned it should be shiny when you encounter it, may need to check which pokemon you caught from the list and adjust the delay
https://github.com/LegoFigure11/swsh-overworld-rng-gui
theres a full manual on there with the tool, and theres a few youtube guides if you type in things like 'swsh overworld rng'
theres several tricks that mean you dont have to spam 4000 animations like date skipping or changing to the party menu

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53050516
Cyclizar simply would not be banned if it didn't have regenerator. Orthworm would probably not be banned yet, but looking for a suspect if it did have regenerator.

Orthworm's stats suck but still has enough utility with hazards and phys bulk to where adding regenerator would put it on the chopping block. Shed Tail is not broken in a vacuum, and Baton Passing took so long to be banned literally because people wanted to preserve fair, balanced interactions like drypassing and subpassing compared to speedpass. A move that takes a exceedingly fair and relatively low power strategy and makes it much more efficient is not broken. Combining it with an ability that removes all the risk and cost of that move does. Cyclizar isn't broken for enabling strong pseudo-baton pass strategies, its for being able to do it at zero risk the entire game, multiple times per game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53050629
Orthworm with Regenerator would be used even more than Cyclizar because of
>Stealth Rock resistance
>Low speed meaning slow pivots, protecting the substitute's integrity
>Can hazard stack when predicting a powerful hit so your turn isn't wasted
>Very hard to OHKO physically, can always come back later at a more opportune time
>Doesn't give a shit about status

Orthworm is shit, but Orthworm with Regenerator would be even better than Cyclizar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53048855
Full Heal has been nerfed, so it doesn't last long. It's best used the instant you get CC'd, a second before you anticipate getting CC'd, or right before you feel an interruptable mon is going to use their Ult (Charizard, Tsareena). It sucks as an item because by the time it wears off, the enemy's CC ability cooldown has also worn off. It's mostly good if you're something like a Dragonite and you plan on Rayquaza coinflipping with a Hyper Beam and you DON'T want to get interrupted by a Volt Tackle or whatever.

I run it on Petalsaur who is often grouped up and those couple of seconds of vine whipping-stuns and giga draining are cruicial to your survivability, so being able to survive through a stun or so can make the difference between a teamfight where the enemy was barely damaged or a teamfight where the enemy is all half HP for clean-up duty. Full Heal for Petalsaur in a 1 vs. 1 is fantastic.

>>53055703
>not unless you get FUG
I hate to say it, but I miss the old map. It's like the shitty Zap mechanic and the center pit design was built around anticipation of forced 50 with sub-49% players being on your team. At least if you could tell your team was shit early on, you could snipe Zapdos and get pretty good at it. But the new map makes it incredibly hard to reliably do it, and Ray still functions in a similar role to Zap where it's just a game changer if you get it. Early Ray you could lose and still defend from a few caps, which made the caps you did earlier worth so much more.

Now, the shield + capping buff may as well be defenseless goals. There's barely a fucking difference. Upon release, I was on teams that were able to guard at least 40% - 50% of the time, even after losing Ray. There were a bunch of games people didn't even go after the dragon and backcapping became and actual, viable strat. Now I have guarded and won after losing Fug maybe 3 times total, and that was because the enemy was mostly dead after getting the snipe. Plus, Fug's lower HP just encourages retards to start coinflipping him and it adds so much fucking stress to the fight that just isn't needed.

>>53049639
A theoretical if Tyranitar could learn Rock Slide (legal), Power Gem (legal), or Meteor Beam (illegal).

The legal Rock Slide change is 15.189 DPS (37.58 ER).
That's still out-performed by Rhyperior with 15.931 DPS (39.51 ER) and Tyrantrum with 16.018 DPS (37.4 ER).
Mega Tyranitar would have 18.132 DPS (47.84 ER), out-performing Mega Aerodactyl with 17.864 DPS (42.49 ER), but losing to the unreleased Mega Diancie which may have 20.42 DPS (46.2 ER).

The illegal Meteor Beam change is a wash, gaining a 20.171 DPS (53.22 ER) thanks to bulk to substantiate a 977.6 TDO.

This is without specifying an opponent mind you. For Mega Blaziken raids, Mega Aerodactyl may be a better choice for being neutral against fighting damage, instead of doubly weak.

13-15

15-17

+18

>>53019210
Depends on what you want out of it.

It IS a competitive fighting game, despite the superficially arena fighter-esque elements: The game still has unique movelists per characters, cancels, just-frames, an attack height system, etc, and the replay value still comes from playing against other people and improving rather then having a ton of modes or single player content. It is much more Street Fighter and less Naruto Ultimate Ninja Storm/DBZ budokai.

That said, for a competitive fighting game, it's approachable: There's no motion inputs, everything is either a button, a button plus a direction, two buttons, or holding and releasing a button, so at a low/starting level it's easier to pick up. The way the game handles attack heights and the whole 2d-3d shift mechanic also gives players more breathing room: The phase shift mechanic means you'll never be stuck in the corner the entire match because shifts will break you out of the 2d phase and back into the 3d phase where you're on more neutral ground, and heights exist not as a way to bypass and punish blocking, but to bypass and punish other moves during their active frames, meaning as a newbie you're not worrying about blocking high or low, rather height is a tool for YOU to use when you're on the defensive to get a reversal and hit through one of your enemy's moves.

Note this does not mean that there's less depth at a higher level of play: Some combos, tech, etc top players will be using take a lot of precise timing and dexterity (Garchomp's charge input run stance cancels are as such a lot of chomp players have to change their button layout) , and the whole phase shift mechanic is actually a huge source of an adapational and resource mangement skillgap at top play where players intentionally alter their combo composition and move choices on the fly to cause or delay shifts based on what's to their advantage; and there's still height mixups even if there's not height based blocking

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019273
>>53019210
cont:

> and there's still height mixups even if there's not height based blocking

For example, if you have a move that bypasses and punishes move of X height, and the other player knows you have that, then they can try to use a different combo starter or meaty/on wakeup move or combo ender to try to punish you trying to punish that height

Basically, while it's said so often it's a cliche, Pokken really is "Easy to learn, hard to master": The changes Pokken makes to the fighting game template targets the sort of stuff new players tend to struggle with (motion inputs, being kept in the corner, dealing with what height to block), but those changes don't actually erase the skillgap at high level play and actually add more depth when it comes to neutral (when both players are trying to get a hit in and outwit the other player), having to adapt rather then flowchart, etc: The fact shifts break you back to a neutral state and the height system enables reversals really means there's a lot more back-and-forth where both players are in the driver's seat of the match.

But like any fighting game, you'll get out what you put in: The fun comes from learning, improving, and playing matches, not from unlocks or modes.

>>53019284
Firstly, I think worrying about "is X a good character to start with" is sort of a bad approach to getting into a fighting game: If there's a character or a game you like, start playing. If you worry about getting all the resources (not that frame data, combo guides, common punishes, etc aren't good to know) or starting with an easy character, you can easily pysche yourself out and put off just playing and learning the game/character you actually wanna play.

That being said, he actually is I think one of the easiest characters to start with. He has relatively short combos and just needs like a few stray grabs or short combos or single hits to do big damage. The drawback is he can struggle to get in to land those hits.

>>53019485
The phase shift system is entirely predictable/under the player's control, the tutorial just doesn't explain it.

3d > 2d shifts happen on basically any heavy hit or with most specials. Some lights cause it too. Basically, anything other then light projectiles will shift from 3d to 2d. This is why the game is more a 2d fighter then a 3d one: The 3d phase is basically just an additional buffer layer of neutral play.

2d > 3d shifts occur when the PSP guage is filled, and different moves, on hit, will add more or less points to that guage. Combos that hit 21 hits long also always auto-shift (as an anti-infinite mechanic), as does the universal grab (but not command grabs). However, the guage isn't in the UI, it's something you have to learn and memorize if you wanna keep track of it.

At high level play, players will alter their combos as the match goes on to always end on shifts to do optimum damage vs the shift interrupting the combo. Or they may intentionally go for combos or moves that maybe do less damage or aren't as safe, but that add less PSP, so shifts DON'T happen (thereby keeping the other player in the corner and under pressure, and maybe to get the chance to land an additional combo for more damage in that phase in the long term) or for combos that maybe don't do as much damage but do EXTRA PSP to shift faster, in case they wanna get out of pressure themselves or get the meter/health regen causing a shift gives you. Some moves also reduce or reset the PSP guage.

But like when you're starting out, I wouldn't worry about it that much: Just remember universal grabs always auto shift, heavy hits in the 3d phase shift to 2d, and the more hits you land in 2d the faster you shift to 3d. As it applies to machamp, you should also remember your command grabs do NOT add PSP, so you can use then in the 2d phase as much as you want, and wake up slap REDUCES the guage, allowing you to keep the enemy in the 2d phase longer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019666
>allowing you to keep the enemy in the 2d phase longer.

Just in case it's not obvious, the reason you want this is because Machamp is a lot better in the 2d phasr then the 3d phase.

Machamp is slow, and is his 3d phase projectiles suck. It's very difficult for machamp to win the field phase and cause the 3d > 2d shift, and he can't do much damage while in the 3d phase.

But even stray hits or single grabs in the 2d phase by machamp do insane damage. It's still hard to actually approach the enemy though, so once machamp IS up close in the 2d phase or especially when you've got the other character in the corner, it's in your interest to keep them there and to continue to land command grabs and rack damage up without causing a shift, most of the time, because it's hard to get back to that position.

In practice, tho, there are obviously situations where you may wanna giove up your advantagious position to land a combo rather then a command grab even if it shifts and allows the enemy to escape: Maybe you aren't comfortable yourself at the moment and just wanna take the damage you can get, maybe you'd really benefit from the extra meter causing a shift brings, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019666
>>53019685
Also also, to be clear, the PSP guage works indepedently for both players.

If you land like 4 hits and almost max out the PSP guage, the enemy landing a hit won't shift: each person has their own guage.

And again, there is no actual visible guage you can look at, sadly: You either need to remember the PSP value of each move, or just reemerge "if I use X move Y times, it will shift" or "If I use Z combo and then land Y move, that will be enough to shift" etc

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I had this dream last night. I don’t really play a lot of Pokémon, and I just come to /vp/ every now and again, so it was kinda weird to have it out of nowhere. In the dream I was out eating dinner with some friends when an old waiter came over and said “you look sad,” I didn’t really know what he was talking about as I was having a good enough time so I just said “nope, I’m doing alright.” He then gave a melancholy smile and said “would you like to see something interesting?”

At that point I was a bit weirded out, but my friends said they’d go and I figured why not. When led us to the front door of the restaurant, opened it, and we walked out into a much more colorful world. Not like somebody turned up the RGB, but colorful in a way I had forgotten. I looked down and I was 10 years old again, I looked at my friends and they were too. The world surrounding us was like the world 20 years ago, but only in the most wholesome, beautiful way. I turned around, and the restaurant had been turned into a Pokémon center and there were various pidgy’s in the trees and rustling in the bushes of other Pokémon you could just catch glimpses of. The atmosphere felt like something from gen 1 or 2, but in the most real, tangible way.

I looked up some steps to the Pokémon center, and there was the old waiter, but now he was 20 years younger. I walked up and asked him what happened, and what was this place. He said something along the lines of “you’ll only be here for a short while, enjoy it while you can.” So me and my friends ran around with the carefree attitude of a child just taking it all in, but all the while there was that sneaking anxiety of knowing we were on a time limit and this could be over soon. We had just gotten to a Pokémon themed casino, when I woke up.

I don’t know why but the whole thing has left me in a melancholy mood.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Many people have National Park, Azalea Town or Ecruteak City as their most emotional/nostalgic music from Gen 2, but for me it's Violet City. The way Go Ichinose used broken chords to give the illusion that more voices are being played, while adhering to the 3-poly limit of the GB soundchip, is nothing short of impressive.

Just right at the beginning of the track, you can hear the Emaj7 - D#m7 - C#m7 - Fdim - Bmaj - F#maj progression and it hits you right in the feels. And that move to the parallel minor key by using the bVII to move from the tonic to the bVI is just absolutely lovely. And let's not forget to mention that infamous IV V iii vi that is used in the B section of the track. It's just pure love to my ears.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4zyXmnvnZ0k
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OA1l8mqfld8

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53042152
If i had to compare the 2:

Crystal clear: gen 2 taken to it's limit in terms of features, giving the player as many options as possible to explore the world (variable level gyms, being able to trade evolve mons without having to connect outside, being able to progress in any direction you want, fully visible pokemon stats etc.)

Polished crystal: Gen upgraded with up to gen 7 features in a way that doesn't harm what made gen 2 good. I would recommend it for people who started with more recent games and want to experience classic johto without having to deal with obsolete/unbalanced mechanics.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53041903
Instead of 2.2.0 I'd recommend picking up the latest nightly release of 3.0.0 beta from the project's GitHub, comes with more QoL features like modernized Box GUI

https://github.com/Rangi42/polishedcrystal

Or you can check out the 9bit fork, which expands the possible number of Pokemon in the Pokedex beyond vanilla rom's limit of 254-ish monsters. However it's less stable than the beta from above, expect to run into glitches if you choose to play this one.

https://github.com/Rangi42/polishedcrystal/tree/9bit

>What is it?
https://www.pokeclicker.com/
Pokéclicker is an open-source game built around the story and content of the Pokémon games. This is an idle & clicker type game that is currently in beta release phase. New content and patches are released frequently.

>Crobat?
https://crobat4.github.io/pokeclicker/
A modified version of Pokeclicker that features QoL changes from the original, including a Dock shortcut, type-based pokeball selection, Gen 3+ berries being available in dungeons, un-nerfed experience gains, and some egg-exclusive pokemon being available through other means.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53054649
Vitamins only benefit the pokemon when it is hatched.
What good is a vitamin on a pokemon, if you don't hatch that egg anymore?
It doesn't do anything but change the time, and points you get from hatching pokemon.

Meaning removing it, won't do anything to the pokemon's stats, unless you want to start hatching the eggs again.

Its good they allow you to reallocate it to a pokemon of which can make better use of it for your hatching habits.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: An NPC mentions her by name in the SM demo back before the games were released, and she's mentioned once or twice again around the resort in the actual games. Most people had no idea who she was and complained that she was some random person compared to the League being people you already know. I personally thought it was payoff in a Chekhov's gun sort of way. There's no point in naming a character several times and including one of those instances in a demo where the text is far more limited unless you're going to utilize that character. It's like how the only mention of Lorelei in Gen I outside of her room is by Ken Sugimori's stand-in within Celadon City where he names cute girl Trainers that he designed (Misty, Erika, Sabrina, and Lorelei). Except that people act like Kahili is some weird exception when frankly most Elite Four didn't really appear outside their rooms before Gen V. DP had Flint's stuff with Volkner in Sunyshore, while Platinum gave them a double battle and had Lucian appear in the Canalave Library to discuss lore, and that was the most the Elite Four had by that point.

This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

Please provide references in ONE image, especially when requesting something outside of the Pokémon universe. If you request something from the old Drawthread or a separate thread, COPY & PASTE the actual request instead of posting a link.

Also, be mindful that requests are done at the discretion of the artists, not on a first come first serve basis.

Please remember to save any piece of art you like from these threads, as we may never know when the archive will start deleting images again. Artists can and are recommended to post their works on other outlets for archival purposes.

>>53036075
>>53029037
I get where you're coming from but it's just excuses, we both know even if you had all your responsibilities removed, your wrist magically healed and were put in an environment where you had nothing to do for entertainment except draw you'd find a reason why you wouldn't.

It's ironic that you mention "retarded drunk child's doodles" because what do you think people think of me? It's just another way to rationalize not drawing so you don't have to face the opinions of other people.

I don't say all this to be an asshole or feed the self-deprecation cope, you can change; you just have to take the first step and trust that the resources and people you surround yourself with can help you be the best artist you can be.

It might come off as a cope to some since i'm seen as a "bad" artist but i think i've made some cool things over the years that wouldn't have existed had i not made a leap of faith.

You just have to believe that one day you're going to be able to fight in the same arena as these people. Thank you for listening to my ted talk.

>Its attack stat is literally its highest stat.
120 is a solid Attack, but without boosts it's rather straightforward to fuck over with the many far faster attackers or some of the walls. 95/65/75 defenses with 60 speed means that it's not getting in the first hit and has trouble taking them.

>Its signature move is literally a physical attack with or without Bulk Up
The 75 Power one that reduces the target's Special Attack, being a bad attack that offsets its other lackluster defense? It's a niche wallbreaker without G-Max or enormous amounts of setup, but if it gets setup then it becomes a wrecking ball.

It can do all of its setup at priority, being the highest-output set by far, but also the riskiest because it's a Slow Frail Mixed Attacker.

Buffing Stockpile, Swallow, and Spit Up would make a lot of weak pokemon better. Greatly improving Swallow/Spit Up is balanced by needing to waste a turn using Stockpile first, and buffing Stockpile makes those wasted turns less painful if something happens.

>Stockpile
-Can stack up to 6 times
-User retains stacks when switching or dying

>Swallow
-Only consumes one stack
-Always heals for 75% HP

>Spit Up
-Only consumes one stack
-Normal Type
-150 Base Power
-30% chance to poison

I've heard skeb is a good option for contacting Japanese (and occasionally Chinese and Korean) artists, but ofc ymmv depending on how well their english tends to be. There's also tumblr, but idk how they'd feel about involvement with a 4chan-y adjacent project (might as well keep that subtle). also a lot of deviantart artists have left for newgrounds and twitter since the big AI scandal so idk. some of the art I pitched in ITT comes from kofi, like the Diantha x Cynthia art found here >>53048998

if you can get the great firewall there's weibo, baidu and wechat, but I've never done anything more than local off wechat (and that was for food). Wechat also has its own pay system you have to setup like visa so idk about that even if you aren't scared of the ccp or something, but it might be the only way to commission art from a lot of chinese artists that don't take paypal for whatever reason. One of my friends has tutored for a kid using wechat before but that was a tiring process and she says she wouldn't do it again (mostly because the parents were too dumb to use zoom)

I'm currently in the process of looking at some redditors to commission art but not for lewds

best of luck tho

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53043330
Hey, that's cool. I was just curious since the threads here always seems collector focus.

Radiant Pokemon are Pokemon that you can only have one of in your deck, but they're have powerful effects or attacks. So it's fun to try and choose which Radiant you want to use or work into your deck. Pic rel is one of the most popular ones, discard pile setup and drawing is really good for a lot of decks.

Radiant Eternatus is the main new one from CZ people like. When you bench it, you can search your deck for any two VMAX Pokemon and bench them as well. Which opens up a lot of opportunities for faster VMAX play.

>DLC is called The Marigold Mission
>Act 1: The Bold North - July 7th 2023
>Act 2: The Deep Dream - November 10th 2023
>Act 3: The Ultra Beyond - 2024
>This is not announced during Pokemon Day, it will interrupt a Nintendo presentation around the release of the first act with Jacq hacking/crashing the livestream and explaining the exciting situation
>After your feats in the story, you’re contacted by Madame Marigold, Clavell’s sister who lives in Northern Paldea
>Marigold runs Manzana Academy, an advanced school for champion-level trainers that serves as an agency of sorts to aid with major conflicts across the world
>After the Area Zero situation, you and your three friends have been invited to spend a semester at the academy, where Marigold has a special mission for you
>The Bold North has Marigold sending you to the Kalos region, which has recently experienced an outbreak of Titan Pokemon
>Tera energy doesn’t reach Kalos so you must learn of Mega Evolution in order to defeat the titans
>Marigold gives Scarlet players a Larvitar with Tyranitarite and Violet players a Bagon with Salamencite
>Titans are: Dedenne, Talonflame, Aegislash, Drapion, Barbaracle, Vivillon, Avalugg, and Mega Garchomp
>Kalos looks noticeably different, only crossover characters are Bonnie who is middle aged and silver fox Sycamore
>Megas can be used in Paldea, all Mega mons are present except Hoenn starters
>The Deep Dream has Marigold sending you into the untapped depths of Area Zero

After I got over my Water type obsession phase because of Blastoise and I love Nautical themes which I tried to become a knockoff Sailor class, I used to be a Bug Maniac and it was the only type I'll used, sometimes I had to get into debates with my younger Brother trying to defend the usefulness of Bug Pokemon like being good status conditioners and synergic teamplayers while he sees them as useless and only believe in the Unga Bunga way of only damage moves matters also he doesn't like Bug IRL while I actually like Bugs IRL.

GF were giving Bug types powerspikes to where they weren't seen as just fodder, but some of the newer Gen 9 Bugs are Suicidal teammates...

I still like Water types, but I been ignoring them mostly, I still catch Bug types for mostly Novelty reasons and usually use the ones that you can tell GF actually cares about because those ones are the only ones who aren't sabotaged into fodder, but now I'm mostly a Fairy Main for so many reasons and it's cool there's finally a Bug/Fairy mon.

The Crustle line is my favorite Bug mon, btw, with the Parasect line in 2nd, because Crabs are my favorite in Pokemon and Animal IRL, so it's safe to assume I like every Crustacean mon like the newest one Klawf, I even like Crabominable which I didn't even like before until Tinkaton learning Ice Hammer from it which forced me to raise one and it just grew on me since then, and Orbeetle is my 3rd because it's a Badnik.

It's a shame, we may never see Mega Beedrill/Pinsir/Heracross again...

Bugs are great, they are one of the types who aren't just one color and have such unique designs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Voice acting in anything that isn't natively English is going to be shit 90% of the time because it's treated like how it is: a frivolous addition. It's not something anything needs to succeed and it's not taken seriously by anybody who actually makes things. The entry barrier is so low the people in the industry have to gatekeep the living shit out of the "profession" because for every voice actor demanding a better wage you have ten thousand blue haired nerdy fatasses who will do it for even cheaper just to be involved with their favorite series without having to do any actual work, and when studios only care about cutting costs that's who they're going to hire if they really feel pressured to add it since hiring real actors is too expensive.
Just have the devs voice act, it's cheaper and more memorable to hear a programmer stumble through some lines than some "career VA" who can only sound like a 12 year old's impression of Goku.

>>53049306
I only liked like 3 of SWSH's pokemon, so SV is a better dex, to me. However, like you said, this dex is less cohesive. I do feel like who ever was in charge of the models (human and pokemon) messed up big time. The humans look uncanny (especially the trainer classes) and the pokemon feel like they were designed in 3d first.

If they just hired good 3d designers or went back to designing pokemon on paper first and then making the model (no matter how tricky it gets) it would be more cohesive and visually pleasing. The biggest problems with GF is that they first: do not retire staff who have overstayed their welcome (can't do 3d programming or design), they don't promote and hire enough new talent, and they do not want to give adequate development time because of the merch/anime. Now, Japan doesn't retire or fire senior staff so this will never change, but they could let their new competent staff do more and implement new ideas (PLA was a big step in the right direction). They could also focus on making the anime longer with more complex story and actual character development and making more merch of the current/previous gen. Thank you for listening to my Ted Talk.

>>52985048
>>52988537
The multiple abilities/innates is something with a lot of potential, but I just do not think the way Exceeded implemented it is good.
It's just egregiously awful that so many abilities have additional effects added to them. What the fuck? It's a system built around multiple abilities. If you want multiple effects, you should put them in different abilities to mix and match instead of trying to shove it into a single ability.
I hope the Voyager hack does multiple abilities better. Are there any other hacks implementing multiple abilities?
Anyways, some of my ideas for multiple ability systems:
>separate abilities into innate and learned
>innate abilities can't be changed, reinforcing the pokemon species' identity and playstyle
>learned abilities are either earned through level up from a specific pool in a manner similar to moves, or through special conditions in a manner similar to special evolutions
>learned abilities can be passed down through breeding, allowing for new synergies with abilities not normally learned
>don't allow for a free for all ability fest, as it weakens the reinforcement of a pokemon species' identity and playstyle, as well as enable lazy and broken combos.

>>52991405
>>52991401
If Tyranitar can have any 3 abilities from a pool of 10 that just makes guessing which ability combo your foe's using exponentially harder unless there is literally only one good option.

I love this Innate system. Unironically the best shit I've seen in any hack in decades. Though I do wish RNG was removed from the Innates. Also can "When this Pokemon makes contact with the enemy" and "When the enemy makes contact with this Pokemon" abilities trigger from either type of Contact? A Goodra hitting a foe should apply the Gooey speed loss just like when Goodra is being hit by a foe.

Reminds me of how Effect Monsters worked in Yugioh, back when you had to choose between a strong Normal Monster without an effect (in this case, a strong pokemon with a relatively boring ability/innate set) and an Effect Monster whose effect makes up for his lack of direct power (innates designed to make the pokemon interesting, maybe even strong). And because these Innates are designed for the Pokemon, things actually feel somewhat balanced. Sure, some effects used RNG like Barrel Dragon but that was rare.

I have never actually used a Rattata on my team before. Except when I was 9 and I'd catch shitmons to use as decoys sent out to die when item-healing my Vaporeon and Charizard and Kadabra. But this game makes me want to experiment with gimmicky underpowered shitmons that could finally help my team or serve a useful niche besides "Well SOMEBODY needs to use HMs" or "Guess somebody has to be my Flying type until I can catch the one I want".

>>52994345
I have no clue if there's a more reliable way but from what I've found, copypasting specific variations of autotiles seemingly requires you to do the manual box selection and copy paste the tiles to wherever you need them. unfortunately bringing them to separate layers will require you to copypaste from something that has said tile on the same layer
but if you're trying to copypaste stuff onto other maps you'll have to do an entire process because for some reason the program clears the clipboard when you move over to different maps
>open a separate project that isn't the one you're currently working with
>paste the selected tiles onto whatever map is open in the second project
>do NOT deselect
>move back to the main project window
>switch maps to whatever you're trying to paste things to
>move back to project #2, making sure whatever you pasted is still selected
>copy
>move back to main project
>paste

rmxp is otherwise decently intuitive so I have no clue how they shat the bed so hard in this specific aspect

I tackled this issue, at least with regards to bugs, by moving then to midgame and buffing their stats. Since our games are hacks, it is important to be honest with yourself that anyone playing them has already played a lot of pokemon games, and therefore you'll want to shake things up some. The first warning sign of a hack, for me, is if the first 3 routes contain ALL early route mons (bugs, regional normal types regional bird) crammed into the same space in an 8+ pokemon encounter table
Dreadful.
Become comfortable with shifting Pokemon from places you're used to them being, and be prepared to adjust their stats a little accordingly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53022834
>You're desperately trying to find holes
This is the umpteenth time you've responded to criticism with "YOU'RE JUST TRYING TO DISPROVE MY APPROACH!"
Anon, that's what discussion is - identifying talking points about a system you have proposed. The fact that the points are overwhelmingly criticism should prompt you to reflect on why those criticisms are being made, and addressing them in your response or through revision of your game mechanics. Nobody is "trying to find" holes - they are pointing out flaws that are immediately obvious.
Also
>Bug types are fixed by throwing resistances on them
Hardly. A large share of the issue is that bug types are inherently kneecapped, due to their tendency towards early game distribution and rapid evolution. For balance purposes, these things can't have 500 BST immediately available at level 10, when everything else is hovering around 400. This is half-addressed by adding a few single-stage strong bugs in the mid-late game, but doesn't address that others remain utterly useless (for example, Wormadam is a pain to try to use at any point in platinum due to how weak it is)
Redistributing bugs and rewarding them with better BSTs allows them to keep their identity of "raised quickly" while not needing to sacrifice their ability to stand up in the late game.

Outsider looking in, gave the dex a quick skim through. Innates seem really interest and a great way of making otherwise over looked pokemon worth looking at. My main issues are one that a lot of them seem to be either really overloaded with additional features.
A lot of them also seem to contain VERY questionable balance choices. Why does Speedforce also give partial immunity to paralysis? shouldn't that be the natural counter to an ability that powerful? I also agree that the fairy spite thing is kinda weird.

Also, I'm not sure how to feel about Levitate giving Magnemite and Koffing partial flying type stab. I might get yelled at for this, but might it be a better idea to create another innate called "Winged" that does the same thing as levitate and put the flying type stab on that?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53033701
NTAs but I agree with all of that.
Some innates are just dumb like the anti-fairy innates, and others seem like they could/should be split in two, especially something like Levitate as you mentioned which just doesn't fit certain pokemon. Magnemite and other "non-flying" levitaters should get a different kind of bonus to go with their levitate, like an electric-themed levitate or a ghostly-themed levitate for pokemon like Gengar, just giving them flying STAB is awkward.

Although the hack is treading ground most people are afraid to tread, so a bit of unbalance or theme oversight is expected, especially since he decided to tackle the entire dex at once. Hopefully more hacks like it take off so the depth and balance of it can be properly honed, he executed the idea pretty well and I wanna see more of it

>>53054691
>Giselle and Ash
As per her introduction episode, Giselle doesn't really force ash to be much of anything, instead they unconsciously mimic each other
Years into the relationship, they have adopted the best and worst traits of the other.
Ash is meaner, Giselle is nicer and less bossy. They're both more competitive than ever.
Ash's spontaneous battle strategies are whittled down a bit over time into battle styles that are "objectively" superior. Battle styles proven to work.
His win rate goes up, but because he's operating on pure tested theory and not his own experience and intuition, he no longer manages to win by upset, often capping out in the semi finals against trainers with quirkier battle choices

He's grown to believe such battle choices are childish, not through coercion but simply convincing himself that in spite of her lesser experience, Giselle's ideas are logically sound on paper. He fades into the ether as a dime-a-dozen competent trainer

As depressing as this might sound, any sadness Ash feels about this is really just fleeting nostalgia. With Giselle in his life Ash is an archetypal mature man, able to let things go. He's still competitive, but not hyped up on pathos. Its a much different route that will probably yield success, though without the gambling strats he used to apply, he won't get those quick surprising wins

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53049007
It's all about learning from experience to be honest with you, I've been using Buyee for many years and will admit that in the beginning I didn't know the tricks that would help me save money. Mandarake is probably the best site for getting stuff from Japan also, I just like being able to use Yahoo Auctions. I just need a friend in Japan who I can get to send stuff over to me desu, I'd obviously pay them a 'commission' for helping me out.

But to get back to what you said, yeah there are a lot of hidden fees (on Buyee, people don't realise that you need to cover the cost of domestic shipping + the service fee) that really mount up. And depending on where you live, import charges can really screw you over. I now only buy from sellers who pay for domestic postage and I never pay the service fee. It's not perfect, but I absolutely would not advocate using eBay for Japanese goods. While Japanese eBay sellers are all angels who always send me extra goodies, they inflate the prices of their stuff and then eBay also slaps on extra fees, The moral of the story is just to be as conscious of where you might incur charges as possible.

Amazon JP is a very good site but I don't know if it sells booster boxes, I would assume it does?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53046561
If you like vintage arts more than modern arts then focus on vintage. A good first step is to pick an era to focus on. You could focus on early WotC (Base, Jungle, Fossil) or Neo or e-Series (Expedition, Aquapolis, Skyridge). Even ex era if you consider it vintage (it’s my personal favorite era).

Once you pick an era find out as much info as you can about it - chase cards, market prices, print runs, etc. Then you just watch the market best as you can. Even if you’re just buying singles for a binder you need to make sure you know what good prices are for the cards you’re targeting. And always triple check for condition when you can. Pester eBay sellers for as many photos as you can get and ask specific questions about surface damage, chipping, and whitening that might not be visible in pictures. If you don’t care about condition so much, still use it to your advantage to negotiate for lower prices.

I missed a lot of stuff I’m sure but start there.
